Author: jorian#4555
Content: which you use to query the chain

Author: jorian#4555
Content: so yes, you connect to a different node for each assetchain

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Ok. So then I guess if you have KMD supported, it would be pretty easy to also support asset chains because everything is the same except for the port and name (and maybe some other parameters)?

Author: jorian#4555
Content: yep

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Ok thanks a lot!

Author: jorian#4555
Content: but, name is not the only identifier. if you define a chain with name ANDY and a premined supply of 20, and another chain called ANDY with a supply of 40, they will both be completely different chains, with different rpc port

Author: Andy#1801
Content: So name+supply is the identifier?

Author: Andy#1801
Content: I found this list: https://github.com/jl777/komodo/blob/dev/src/assetchains.json

Author: jorian#4555
Content: no, even more. i don't know which parameters are the identifiers, maybe @blackjok3r can enlighten

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically all -ac parameters affect the chain magic

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @Andy that list are the chains that have dPoW enabled

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: change anything and it is a different chain

Author: Andy#1801
Content: So then I guess there is still a little more to it (eg. to prevent "replay" attacks)

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: yes, there are like 2 ac params that allow height activation that do not change magic, everything else does.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: block 1 will be different for all assetchains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then with the first notarization, it becomes permanent

Author: Andy#1801
Content: and if I try to create the exact same asset chain that someone has already created, it will be able to match that and then use the existing one?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: identical parameters will connect to the same chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assuming you know the ip address of at least one of the existing nodes

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Ok, thanks a lot for the help so far. I'm just trying to get a feel for how much work is involved regarding integrating that into a wallet. I'll have to do a deep-dive once we actually start integrating.

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Are there public nodes that you can query over HTTP? Or a list of asset-chains and a node you can connect to?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you should be able to have a COIN variable that is used to talk to the different daemons. if issuing rpc calls via komodo-cli just add -ac_name=<COIN>

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it talking to the rpc port, then find the rpc port for each coin and can use curl or equivalent to that port

Author: Andy#1801
Content: ok makes sense. Is there a standard "indexer" or "middleware" that can be used to get things like transaction histories etc? I saw you use bitpay insight, but since that one is deprecated, maybe there is a new one?

Author: Andy#1801
Content: That will be my last question, promised üòõ

Author: jorian#4555
Content: you can never ask too many questions

Author: jorian#4555
Content: we'd rather have millions of questions than no questions

Author: jorian#4555
Content: insight is still a thing though

Author: jorian#4555
Content: https://dexstats.info/explorers.php lists all explorers for all chains known

Author: Andy#1801
Content: I believe people should try to read first and try to figure it out themselves, and only after that ask questions. There's a reason why people write FAQs and blogposts.

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Thanks! That website was exactly what I was looking for üòÉ

Content: üëç

Author: Andy#1801
Content: üëç

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Andy just sync the chain with -addressindex=1 and -spentindex=1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then the daemon directly supports the address based calls to get balances, utxo, history

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is what the explorers use

Author: Andy#1801
Content: ok, will do üòÉ

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@Andy the insight api from the explorers does work

https://github.com/DeckerSU/insight-api-komodo#api-http-endpoints
all of them should work, just replace
`insight-api` with `insight-api-komodo`
ex: https://kmdexplorer.io/insight-api-komodo/tx/a61ff1eee265777890a1c87f286d93ff5d45c336f3c22ac7b0b0b287e580c3f9

but the explorers have ratelimits so be vary about that
alternately you could run your own explorer for any assetchain you want using
https://github.com/gcharang/komodo-install-explorer

Author: jorian#4555
Content: the explorers itself don't have a rate limiter if you don't set one.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: yeah, official ones do have ratelimits

Author: jorian#4555
Content: this falls outside the discussion, but those rate limiters are nginx limiters, not limiters from insight. all except the dexstats.info explorers suffer from that

Author: Decker#3767
Content: @Deleted User you can't sign the tx offline ... bcz to sign raw transaction signer should know the vin amounts (!) ... this form requesting it from explorer. It can be implemented by other way, but it will be like a hell to users ... bcz they should enter each vin amount without any errors, otherwise sign will be incorrect.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: That's why i implement it user-friendly, just enter unsigned tx, it will request vin amounts automatically and sign it.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: vins included ... txid and vout_num ... but not amount ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: unsigned tx doesn't contain any information of vins amount.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: use `decoderawtransaction` in komodod and you will understand.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: you will unable to answer on question "what's the amount of vin[0]" ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: bcz your unsigned tx contains only txid and n fields.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: )) automatically ... if you will enter vin amounts ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: created raw transaction will be without vin amounts anyway ... you will need to specify it separately at signing stage.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: with sapling ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: just always remember one thing - unsigned raw tx don't contain vin amounts info. but for signing - it's needed.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: where you get it - from explorer, from your memory, doesn't matter. but for signing it's needed anyway. it's part of a signing process in sapling.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: satoshi design

Author: Decker#3767
Content: if you just need to sign something offline - sync komodod, unplug internet cable and sign.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the amount was put into the spending tx, you would need to validate it anyway to make sure it was indeed the correct value

Author: Decker#3767
Content: without sapling signing changes - all was little bit easier ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: i'm agree.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: @Deleted User if you need to sign OOT tx (as i remember they not enabled sapling) - just clone repo https://github.com/DeckerSU/coinbin/commits/komodo (komodo branch) and revert last 2 commits.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: it's open source ... you can do with it what you want ...

Author: ashwin#5867
Content:
I'm using macOS Mojave. When I use brew link boost I get an error `Linking /usr/local/Cellar/boost/1.70.0... 
Error: Could not symlink include/boost
/usr/local/include is not writable`.... Steps taken 1. `sudo chown -R $USER:admin /usr/local/include` 2. `brew doctor`
Does anybody face this same problem.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: spinning up a linux docker container and doing all KMD development in that will avoid a lot of problems like this, but also requires learning more stuff. Compiling stuff on mac is rarely easy. But you are have a `homebrew` problem, which is deeper. Your homebrew install is broken and the permissions of /usr/local/include wrong. What are they and who owns the directory?

Author: ashwin#5867
Content: Currently, the directory is owned by $USER and the group is admin. The OS behavior is weird however, Ive moved to a Ubuntu system.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ubuntu will let you concentrate on your code instead of other weird errors

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 16.04 and 18.04 seem best. I have a 19.04 and it's "too new" for some things, so beware
